title: Protocol for evaluating CD8+ T cell-mediated immunity in latently SHIV-infected rhesus macaques with HIV fusion-inhibitory lipopeptide monotherapy
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Evaluation of SIVmac239 gag-specific CD8+ T cell responses after LP-98 withdrawal
Timing: 3 days
Timing:  13-17 h to thaw and recover PBMCs
Timing: 7 h for stimulation of PBMCs
Timing: 4 h for staining with fluorescent antibodies for flow cytometry
Timing: 1 day to acquire flow cytometry data
PBMCs are obtained from blood samples taken from the macaques after LP-98 treatment cessation, to explore the effects of LP-98 therapy on CD8+ T cells and the underlying mechanisms. PBMCs are stimulated with the SIVmac239 Gag peptide pool to evaluate the SIVmac239 Gag-specific CD8+ T cell responses (Xue et al., 2022[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]). Degranulation (CD107a), cytokine (IFN-γ, TNF-α and IL-2) and chemokine production (MIP-1β) were chosen as indicators to determine SIVmac239 Gag-specific CD8+ T cell function (Betts et al., 2006[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]; Nguyen et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]). All steps are performed in biosafety cabinet using sterile reagents and plastic consumables.
Thaw and recover PBMCs.
Prepare 15 mL tubes labeled with PBMC IDs.
Transfer 9 mL complete RPMI 1640 medium to 15 mL tubes.
Place cryovials containing cryopreserved PBMCs in a 37°C water bath.
Take cryovials out of the water bath once cells are almost thawed (about 1–2 min) with a small piece of ice remaining.
Transfer 1 mL cell suspensions into 15 mL tubes containing complete RPMI 1640 medium. Mix the cells by pipetting up and down gently.
Count cells.
Pipet 10 μL of resuspended cells to stain with trypan blue.
Transfer the cells into the wells of a Glasstic Slide 10 with counting grids.
Count and calculate the total PBMCs for each sample.
Centrifuge 15 mL tubes at 400 × g for 10 min at 4°C.

Remove and discard supernatants and gently tap the bottom of the tubes to resuspend the cells in the liquid remaining at the bottom of the tubes.
Suspend PBMCs at a concentration of 2 × 106/mL in complete RPMI 1640 medium.
Prepare 48-well plates labeled with ‘negative’, ‘SIVmac239 Gag peptide pool’ and ‘positive’ for each sample.
Seed 500 μL (1 × 106) of PBMCs into each well of 48-well plates.
Culture cells at 37°C in a 5% CO2 incubator for about 12–16 h.
Note: The cell concentration does not have to be 2 × 106/mL in step (i). Users can choose a different cell concentration as long as it is sufficient to ensure seeding 106 PBMCs in each well in step (k). The volume of cells and complete RPMI 1640 medium added to each well depends on the cell concentration, and make sure that there are 106 PBMCs in 500 μL of complete RPMI 1640 medium.
Note: The thawed PBMCs need to be recovered overnight for the SIVmac239 Gag peptide pool stimulation assay. We recommend that cryopreserved PBMCs be thawed in late afternoon and allowed to recover for about 12–16 h.
Note: Please refer to the troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section (problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.1]) for concerns if the number of viable PBMCs after thawing is too low.
Stimulation of PBMCs.
Remove 50 μL solution from each well.
Add 50 μL of SIVmac239 Gag peptide pool working solution (2.5 mg/mL) into each well of the SIVmac239 Gag peptide pool group (at a final concentration of 0.25 mg/mL).
Add 50 μL of complete RPMI 1640 medium per well for the negative group.
Add 50 μL 10 × cell stimulation cocktail solution (at a final concentration of 1 ×) per well for the positive group.

Add 2 μL 250 × brefeldin A solution (at a final concentration of 1 ×) to each well in all experimental groups.
Add 5 μL of BV786 anti-human CD107a antibody per well in all experimental groups.
Mix the reagents and cells by pipetting up and down and culture the cells at 37°C, in a 5% CO2 incubator for 6 h.
Note: In place of SIVmac239 Gag peptides, the SIVmac239 Env peptides, SIVmac239 Pol peptides, SIVmac239 Nef peptides or SIVmac239 Vif peptides can also be used for antigenic stimulation to measure SIVmac239-specific CD8+ T cell immune response. It may be better to test different peptides to reflect the function of CD8+ T cells more broadly.
Note: Users can choose to add costimulatory antibodies (anti-human CD28 antibody and anti-human CD49d antibody) to both negative, positive and SIVmac239 Gag peptide pool groups to yield clearer results in terms of promoting the production of IFN-γ, MIP-1β, TNF-α, IL-2 and CD107a by SIV Gag-specific CD8+ T cells.
Note: Brefeldin A is commonly used to block protein transport processes so that intracellular cytokines accumulate at the Golgi complex/endoplasmic reticulum for better staining.
Note: Users can add GolgiStop to all wells to allow accumulation of intracellular cytokines in the Golgi complex, enhancing the cytokine staining signals for flow cytometric analysis.
Note: We recommend adding anti-CD107a antibody at the start of stimulation because of the transient nature of the surface expression of CD107a on CD8+ T cells. CD107a is located primarily on lysosomal/endosomal membranes, and is rapidly removed via the endocytic pathway in stimulated CD8+ T cells (Betts et al., 2003[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]).

Note: We chose six hours as the optimal stimulation time based on pilot experiments, consistent with that reported in the previous reference (Passaes et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]). Users should perform pilot experiments to determine the optimal incubation time following SIVmac239 Gag peptide pool stimulation that will vary according to the experimental conditions.
Critical: Cells will settle to the bottom after 12–16 h of incubation. Users must gently remove the medium at step (a) to avoid cell loss from the bottom of 48-well plates.
Staining with fluorescent antibodies for flow cytometry.
Prepare round-bottom polystyrene tubes labeled with ‘negative’ and ‘SIVmac239 Gag stimulated’ and ‘positive’ for each PBMC sample.
After stimulation, transfer cells from 48-well plates to tubes.
Wash cells.
Add 2 mL PBS to wash cells.
Centrifuge cells at 350 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
Remove and discard supernatants and gently tap the bottom of the tubes to resuspend cells in liquid remaining at the bottom of the tubes.
Viability stain.
Resuspend cells in 100 μL PBS.
Add 1 μL Zombie NIR fixable viability kit (BioLegend) at a final concentration of 1:100.
Mix cells by vortexing gently and incubate at 25°C for 20 min in the dark.
Wash cells twice.
Add 2 mL FACS washing buffer.
Centrifuge cells at 350 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove and discard the supernatants and gently tap the bottom of the tubes to resuspend cells in liquid remaining at the bottom of the tubes.
Repeat step (i-iii).
Prepare extracellular staining solution.
Calculate the total volume of extracellular staining solution needed according to number of samples (see ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’ section for composition).
Add required volume of FACS washing buffer to a new tube labeled with extracellular staining solution.

Add required volume of BV605 anti-human CD3 antibody and FITC anti-human CD8 antibody to the tube.
Mix extracellular staining solution by vortexing.
Stain extracellular markers.
Resuspend cells in 100 μL extracellular staining solution.
Mix cells by vortexing gently and incubate at 4°C for 30 min in the dark.
Wash cells twice.
Add 2 mL FACS washing buffer.
Centrifuge the cells at 350 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove and discard the supernatants and gently tap the bottom of the tubes to resuspend cells in liquid remaining at the bottom of the tubes.
Repeat step (i-iii).
Fix and permeabilize the cells.
Add 250 μL of fixation/permeabilization solution (BD Biosciences) to each tube.
Mix cells by vortexing gently and incubate at 4°C for 20 min in the dark.
Wash cells twice.
Add 2 mL 1 × Perm/wash buffer (BD Biosciences) to each tube.
Centrifuge the cells at 350 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove the supernatant and gently tap the bottom of the tubes to resuspend cells in liquid remaining at the bottom of the tubes.
Repeat step (i-iii).
Prepare intracellular staining solution.
Calculate the total volume of intracellular staining solution needed according to number of samples (see ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’ section for composition).
Add required volume of 1 × Perm/wash buffer to a new tube labeled with intracellular staining solution.
Add required volume of Brilliant Stain Buffer Plus to the tube.
Add required volume of BV711 anti-human IFN-γ antibody, BV421 anti-human MIP-1β antibody, PE/cyanine7 anti-human IL-2 antibody and BV650 anti-human TNF-α antibody to the tube.
Mix intracellular staining solution by vortexing.
Stain intracellular markers.
Resuspend cells in 100 μL intracellular staining solution.
Mix cells by vortexing gently and incubate at 4°C for 30 min in the dark.
Wash cells twice.

Add 2 mL of 1 × Perm/wash buffer to each tube.
Centrifuge the cells at 350 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove and discard the supernatants and gently tap the bottom of the tubes to resuspend cells in liquid remaining at the bottom of the tubes.
Repeat step (i-iii).
Fix cells.
Add 300 μL of 1% paraformaldehyde to each tube.
Mix cells by vortexing gently and incubate at 4°C for 15–20 min in the dark.
Wash cells twice.
Add 2 mL FACS washing buffer to all tubes.
Centrifuge the cells at 600 × g for 3 min at 4°C.
Remove and discard the supernatants and gently tap the bottom of the tubes to resuspend cells in liquid remaining at the bottom of the tubes.
Repeat step (i-iii).
Resuspend cells in 300 μL PBS.
Store the cells at 4°C in the dark and plan to acquire the data from the experimental cells on the BD Aria II flow cytometer within 24 h.
Note: The viability dye and antibody can be conjugated to different fluorophores depending on the lasers available on the type of flow cytometer used.
Note: When removing the supernatant after centrifugation, remove residual solution by pressing the mouth of the tube on a paper towel for 1–2 s.
Note: Dissolve one vial of Zombie NIR fixable viability dye in 100 μL DMSO at 25°C, and dilute at 1:100–1000 in PBS. The optimum concentration is determined before the experiment by measuring the effect of different concentrations on live cell identification.

Note: In consideration of biosafety in handing samples from SHIVSF162P3 infected rhesus macaques, we choose to fix samples with 1% paraformaldehyde to inactive the SHIV, protecting operators and BD Aria II flow cytometer against SHIVSF162P3 infection. In addition, treating samples with 1% paraformaldehyde can maintain the stability of fluorescence signals among large-sample detection by flow cytometer so that users can acquire enough time to get stable data from cell samples.
Alternatives: FACS washing buffer can be substitute for the commercial cell staining buffer that is useful for the dilution of fluorescent reagents as well as for the suspension, and washing of cells destined for flow cytometric analysis, such as Cell Staining Buffer (Biolegend, Cat#: 420201), Stain Buffer (BD Biosciences, Cat#: 554657), et al.
Critical: Before staining with the Zombie NIR fixable viability dye, cells must be washed and resuspended in PBS without Tris buffer or proteins like BSA.
Acquire flow cytometry data.
Adjust fluorescence detector voltage and compensation appropriately by using a blank tube and positive single fluorescence tubes.
Record data from BD Aria II flow cytometer.
Record data from fluorescence-minus-one (FMO) tubes to define gates for the positive cell populations.
Acquire data from experimental cells in labeled tubes.
Analyze data using FlowJo v10.0 software as outlined in the quantification and statistical analysis[href=https://www.wicell.org#quantification-and-statistical-analysis] section.
Note: Mix cells by vortexing the tubes briefly before running on the flow cytometer to ensure accuracy and reproducibility of data.
Note: Refer to the troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section (problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3]) for concerns if the fluorescence of stained intracellular cytokines is not detected.
Note: Refer to the troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section (problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5]) for concerns regarding inconsistent functional molecule production by SIVmac239 Gag-specific CD8+ T cell in different separate experiments.
Adoptive infusion of anti-CD8 antibody in SVC macaques after cessation of LP-98 treatment
Timing: 8 days

Timing: 8 days to deplete CD8+ T cells
Timing: 3 h to count CD8+ T cells
Timing: 3 h to measure plasma virus RNA
To determine if the fact that the plasma virus of stable virologic control (SVC) macaques remains undetectable after LP-98 treatment cessation was related to a strong CD8+ T cell immune response, we depleted CD8+ T cells by using adoptive infusion of anti-CD8 antibody in SVC macaques. Dynamic changes in CD8+ T cell counts and plasma virus loading were monitored to directly assess the role of CD8+ T cell response (Cardozo et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]).
Deplete CD8+ T cells. SVC macaques were treated by adoptive infusion of anti-CD8 alpha [MT807R1] to deplete CD8+ T cells after LP-98 withdrawal. All animals were anesthetized with 10 mg/kg intramuscular ketamine hydrochloride before performing the following two steps.
Inject anti-CD8 alpha [MT807R1] subcutaneously into SVC monkeys on day 0.
Shave nape of the neck with hair clipper.
Lift the skin and inject 10 mg/kg of anti-CD8 alpha [MT807R1] with needle held horizontally.
Inject anti-CD8 alpha [MT807R1] intravenously into SVC monkeys on days 3 and 7 after the initial anti-CD8 antibody infusion.
Shave hind limb with hair clipper.
Inject 5 mg/kg of anti-CD8 alpha [MT807R1] slowly into the obvious vein on the hind limb (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
Note: We strictly recommend injecting anti-CD8alpha [MT807R1] subcutaneously first followed by two intravenous infusions according to previous reports (Amara et al., 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]; Lifson et al., 2001[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]). We recommend injecting anti-CD8 alpha [MT807R1] subcutaneously at multiple spots at the initial infusion for better absorption.
Count CD8+ T cells.
Prepare round-bottom polystyrene tubes marked with the animal codes.
Pipet 50 μL of peripheral blood into the bottom of each tube.
Prepare extracellular staining solution.

Calculate the total volume of extracellular staining solution needed for the number of samples (see ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’ section for composition).
Add required volume of PBS to a new tube labeled with extracellular staining solution.
Add required volume of APC-anti-NHP CD45 antibody, PerCP-anti-human CD3 antibody, and PE-anti-human CD8 antibody to the tube.
Mix extracellular staining solution by vortexing.
Stain extracellular markers.
Add 50 μL extracellular staining solution to each tube.
Mix cells by vortexing gently and incubate in the dark at 4°C for 30 min.
Add 1 mL of 1 × FACSTM lysing solution to each tube to lyse red blood cells for about 3 min.
Add 1 mL PBS to each tube to stop lysis once liquid becomes clear.
Centrifuge cells at 1100 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove and discard the supernatants and gently tap the bottom of the tubes to resuspend cells in liquid remaining at the bottom of the tubes.
Wash cells twice.
Add 2 mL PBS to each tube.
Centrifuge cells at 1100 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove and discard the supernatants and gently tap the bottom of the tubes to resuspend cells in liquid remaining at the bottom of the tubes.
Repeat step (i-iii).
Add 1 mL of Staining buffer (BD Biosciences) and resuspend cells.
Prepare TrucountTM Tubes (BD Biosciences) labeled with the animal codes.
Transfer 500 μL of cell suspension to TrucountTM Tubes.
Acquire and analyze the data from experimental cells on BD Accuri C6 flow cytometer in time.
Note: Mix peripheral blood fully before pipetting it into the tubes in step (b).

Note: Users should always pay attention to the change of liquid clarity when adding 1 × FACSTM lysing solution to tubes in step (e) and add PBS immediately to prevent excessive lysis and protect lymphocytes in step (f).
Note: Lysing solutions from different suppliers may have different cell lysis capabilities, therefore the incubation time of different lysing solution before the liquid become clear in step (e) should be determined by pilot experiments.
Note: After discarding the supernatants after centrifugation, remove residual solution by pressing the mouth of the tube on a paper towel for 1–2 s.
Measure plasma virus RNA.
The specific steps are the same as those described in “determination of plasma viral RNA level[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.3]” in the “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” section.
Note: Refer to the troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section (problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7]) for concerns regarding lack of fluctuation in plasma vRNA after adoptive infusion of anti-CD8 alpha [MT807R1].
